Award.AwardTitle: Diamagnetic-Levitation based Low-frequency Broadband Vibration Energy Harvester

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
The goal of this research is to provide a low-frequency broadband energy harvester as a solution to the powering of wireless sensors for monitoring structures. Preliminary studies have demonstrated a mono-stable low-frequency energy harvester using diamagnetic levitation (DL). The key features of this energy harvester are its inherent nonlinearity, weak restoring forces and absence of mechanical friction. The proposed energy harvester is a bi-stable horizontal DL system which can undergo large periodic inter-well oscillations and chaotic motions from a range of input accelerations in all three directions. Hence this system can extract output power orders of magnitude more than traditional linear energy harvesters in a broadband frequency range. This research will also involve developing near-optimal and power management solutions for integrating the energy harvester with rechargeable batteries and laboratory tests of the prototypes will be performed to evaluate its performance in real ambient vibrations.

A promising high efficiency energy harvesting system with no apparent mechanical friction and a wide bandwidth in the low frequency range is envisioned to completely cater to the needs of energy harvesting for many engineering applications. Fundamental limits along with conflicting constraints imposed by the size of the harvester, transduction efficiency of the harvester and the energy available for the functioning of the structural health monitoring (SHM) systems will be addressed. A significant advancement in the knowledge of energy harvesting using nonlinear systems can be expected along with creating a framework for using DL in civil, mechanical, and aerospace engineering applications as an interest for systems with no mechanical damping persists for maximum efficiency. With the on-going advances in sensors and sensor network technologies, the proposed research will contribute greatly to the development of truly autonomous and self-sustained SHM systems for monitoring infrastructures.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Wireless sensors provide a range of functions by which a critical infrastructure’s health can be monitored continually or on demand, but they lack dependent power supply to be self-sustained. This bottleneck has led to numerous investigations by researchers around the world to power these wireless sensors from the ubiquitous ambient vibrations present in their environment. The vibrational energy available in these environments are predominately ultra-low frequency in nature, (for e.g., the natural frequency for long-span bridges are lower than 1Hz), are broadband in nature and have low levels of energy. In this project we have investigated the use of a novel magnetic levitation technique stabilized by diamagnetism to develop vibration energy harvesters that cater to this unique and challenging vibrational environment.

Interest in this form of magnetic levitation has been rekindled in the last decade when pioneering researchers demonstrated the mechanism by levitating a frog and by levitating a magnet between two fingers. We took inspiration from these demonstrations and applied it to vibration energy harvesting. Specifically, we developed three different types of vibration energy harvesters using this levitation technique. Two of the vibration energy harvesters were mono-stable nonlinear vibration energy harvesters and the third one was a bi-stable nonlinear vibration energy harvester. We intentionally designed our vibration energy harvesters to have stiffness nonlinearities to make them broadband in nature.

The influence of the strength and geometry of the magnets and the diamagnetic materials in the system, the relative distance between each of them, were critically studied for the three types of the vibration energy harvesters to assess and optimize their effects on the static and dynamic magnetic levitation, levitation gap, size of the system, the magnetic stiffness, the frequency range of operation, and the available vibration energy for harvesting. As a result of the studies several efficient low frequency vibration energy harvesters were built and tested. The energy harvesters met the challenges of low frequency operation, broadband in nature, and being extremely efficient due to the inherent passive friction-free attribute of the magnetic levitation system.

This thorough theoretical and experimental demonstration of research on diamagnetically stabilized magnet levitation and diamagnetic levitation will possibly invoke new applications for these magnetic levitation systems. This may impact emerging fields of micro-fluidics, where there is a need for high precision manipulation of pico-femtoliter volume particles, also micro-electro-mechanical systems (MEMS), where there is a need for highly sensitive micro-nano force sensors, and possibly in other areas of research where there is a need for mechanical friction free systems for enhanced performance.

This project yielded eleven peer-reviewed publications which include seven journal publications, three conference proceedings, and one book chapter. The project provided excellent educational training to a broad spectrum of students, including several doctorate, masters, undergraduates, and high school students. The research work also helped in enriching the already existing graduate course in Structural Health Monitoring.
